In fact, it is Holy Week for all Eastern Orthodox religions. Sunday is the day we celebrate our Easter. }}</ref> | spouse = | occupation = }} '''Eleni Bakopanos''', [[Queen's Privy Council for Canada|PC]] (born 1954 in [[Argos]], [[Greece]]) is a [[Canada|Canadian]] politician. Bakopanos was a member of the [[Liberal Party of Canada]] in the [[Canadian House of Commons]], representing the riding of [[Ahuntsic (electoral district)|Ahuntsic]] from 1997 to 2006, and Saint-Denis from 1993 to 1997 and is the first Greek-born woman to be elected to Parliament. Bakopanos has been an executive, and a policy adviser. Formerly Assistant Deputy Chairman of Committees of the Whole, and a former [[Parliamentary Secretary]] to the [[Minister of Justice (Canada)|Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada]] (1997–1999). Bakopanos was named Parliamentary Secretary to the [[Minister of Social Development (Canada)|Minister of Social Development]] with special emphasis on Social Economy on July 20, 2004. Bakopanos has served as Chair of the Standing Committee on Citizenship and Immigration and as Vice-Chair of the Standing Committee on Canadian Heritage.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.ctv.ca/mini/election2006/candidates/24002_LIB.html Election 2006<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In the spring 2004, Bakopanos wrote a booklet titled ''Political Recruiting and Women in the Political Process''.<ref>[http://www.parl.gc.ca/infoparl/27/1/27n1_04e_bakopanos.pdf 034072-E.vp<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> She argues that women continue to face serious obstacles to full participation in public life. She suggests that women bring a different character to the policy making process and they should be encouraged to enter politics in greater numbers. Bakopanos holds a Bachelor of Arts with honours in political science and history from [[McGill University]], where she also studied law. She is married and is the mother of two daughters.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Bakopanos sought a return to parliament in the [[Canadian federal election, 2008|2008 federal election]], but was unsuccessful. She is running in the provincial riding of [[Crémazie (electoral district)|Crémazie]] in the [[Quebec general election, 2012|2012 election]] for the [[Quebec Liberal Party]]. ==References== {{reflist}} <!--See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <ref(erences/)> tags--> ===General=== *{{cite journal |title=Political Recruiting and Women in the Political Process |last=Bakopanos |first=Eleni |year=2004 |publisher=''Canadian Parliamentary Review'' |location=Ottawa |unused_data=|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/Infoparl/english/issue.asp?param=61&art=40 }} ==External links== * {{CanParlbio|ID=f778349b-4972-42c9-a933-63b201d420b1}} * [http://www.caledoninst.org/Publications/PDF/536ENG.pdf Social Economy Champion in 2005] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Bakopanos, Eleni | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Canadian politician | DATE OF BIRTH = 1954 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Argos, Greece|Argos]], [[Greece]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bakopanos, Eleni}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian people of Greek descent]] [[Category:Canadian women Members of Parliament]] [[Category:Greek emigrants to Canada]] [[Category:Liberal Party of Canada MPs]] [[Category:Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Quebec]] [[Category:Members of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada]] [[Category:McGill University alumni]] [[Category:Naturalized citizens of Canada]] [[Category:People from Argos]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Phoenix (Greece)]] [[Category:Women in Quebec politics]]
